question:
A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for the evaluation of fatigue for several weeks. The parents report that their son quit doing sports at school because of low energy. The patient's academic performance has declined recently. He spends most of his time in the basement playing video games and eating bowls of cereal. He has no history of serious illness. His mother has Hashimoto's thyroiditis and his father has major depressive disorder. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows conjunctival pallor, inflammation and fissuring of the corners of the mouth, and concavity of the finger nails. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 11.5 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume 76 μm3
Platelet count 290,000/mm3
Red cell distribution width 18% (N = 13%–15%)
Leukocyte count 7,000/mm3
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in treatment?"

The patient presents with fatigue, low energy, decline in academic performance, and a sedentary lifestyle, which are common symptoms of anemia. The physical examination findings of conjunctival pallor, inflammation and fissuring of the corners of the mouth, and concavity of the finger nails further support this suspicion. The laboratory results show a low hemoglobin level (11.5 g/dL), low mean corpuscular volume (MCV) of 76 μm3, and an elevated red cell distribution width (RDW) of 18%.

The RDW is a parameter that indicates the variation in size of red blood cells. An elevated RDW suggests the presence of a mixed anemia, which is often associated with iron deficiency anemia. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are consistent with this diagnosis. Iron deficiency anemia is a common cause of anemia in adolescents and young adults, particularly those with inadequate dietary intake or increased iron requirements.

Given the patient's age and symptoms, the most appropriate initial step in treatment would be to address the underlying cause of the anemia, which in this case appears to be iron deficiency anemia. Iron supplementation is a common and effective treatment for iron deficiency anemia, and it is usually the first-line treatment. Regular blood transfusions are not typically necessary for iron deficiency anemia, and allogenic stem cell transplantation is not indicated in this case. Methylphenidate is a medication used to treat attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), which is not suspected in this case.

Therefore, the most appropriate initial step in treatment is iron supplementation.", "answer_choice": "C"}
